user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun(osal_id_t timebase_id, uint32 *freerun_val)
{
    int32                          return_code;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(freerun_val);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, timebase_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, token);

        *freerun_val = timebase->freerun_time;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetFreeRun:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of language/compiler extensions in the provided code fragments. Specifically:
- No compiler-specific keywords or attributes (for example: __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, __extension__, __typeof__, __inline__ with vendor extension syntax, or similar) are present.
- No GCC/clang statement-expressions ({ ... }) or nested functions are used.
- No use of nonstandard keywords or type qualifiers beyond standard C (the code uses typedefs like uint32_t/int32_t and standard 'static inline').
- Macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) expand to ordinary expressions/operations; their definitions shown do not include any compiler-specific constructs. The unknown BUGCHECK macro and other routines/macros not fully shown could potentially contain extensions, but there is no evidence in the provided snippets to classify them as compiler extensions — therefore they cannot be flagged here.

Given the above, there are no code fragments in the provided material that should be investigated for Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions). If you can provide the definitions of BUGCHECK or any other macros/implementation files that use compiler-specific intrinsics, I can re-check those for extensions.
